boardgame.name: Realm Works
boardgame.description:
from the kickstarter
Streamline RPG preparation, spend more time focusing on the game, and increase the engagement of your players with Realm Works!

How many times have you struggled to keep your tabletop RPG campaigns completely organized? Have you ever lost track of what your players have and haven't learned? Is “real-life” limiting the time you have to prepare for games? Do you waste precious time during games searching for details from previous sessions, some of which occurred months or even years ago? These challenges, and others, are what we set out to solve with Realm Works.

Realm Works takes campaign management for tabletop RPGs to the next level, making it faster and easier to prepare for games, and greatly enhancing the actual game experience. You can use Realm Works with any RPGs you play — it’s “game system neutral” and can be used no matter what type of campaign you run. GMs can create, manage, and share their world using a single tool, rather than trying to cobble things together with multiple, disconnected applications. Realm Works was built by GMs and players for GMs and players.

boardgame.name: Fire Call
boardgame.description:
"During the earlier days of firefighting, volunteer fire brigades used deception to compete with one another in order to be the first responders on scene, and subsequently receive payment from the property owner's insurance.

Fire Call positions you at the front lines of modern-day firefighting with a heated twist reminiscent of the combative early years. As you battle opposing fire departments, pull out all the stops to gain control of the most districts by collecting equipment, sabotaging opponents, and successfully completing fire calls to win the game."

The game objective is to become the Fire Department (player) with the most occupied districts by collecting and using the necessary equipment to complete Fire Calls. Once all the districts are covered, the Fire Department with the most occupied districts wins the game.

On their turn, players roll the die and move their markers along the track. The space they land on can have one of a number of effects. Players may gain fire equipment, have the opportunity to complete a fire call and occupy a district, gain cards for special effects later or sustain on-the-job injuries and be put in hospital. Players will also gain ranks throughout the game, starting off as Firefighters and being promoted up to Fire Chief.

When fire calls are completed by players, the corresponding district is covered and occupied. Immediately after all 11 districts are occupied, the game ends and the player with the most wins.

boardgame.name: QuickWits
boardgame.description:
QuickWits is a fast-paced card game based on naming items within certain categories and descriptions. The game is very similar to Anomia, but the content is more mature in theme.

During the game, players take turn drawing a card and placing it in front of them. Each card has one of six different symbols on it, and when two players have the same symbol on the card on the top of their pile, they face off. Each player has to name something in his opponent's card category before his opponent names something in the category on his own card. The fastest player takes his opponent's card and places it face down in his score pile.

The game ends once all the cards have been dealt, and the player with the most cards in his pile wins.

boardgame.name: Kampen om Fredriksten
boardgame.description:
In the family-friendly game Kampen om Fredriksten, players are merchant families in the city Halden in southern Norway during the 17th century. Players run their businesses and try to adapt to the events of the period, all while helping building the fort Fredriksten, which will protect the city from repeated attacks from the Swedish king, Karl XII.

Each round, you roll your dice and use them to activate your buildings. Each building can only be activated by a certain die value, and will provide money, construction material, soldiers, or victory points. If you erect buildings with different dice values, you will be able to utilize your dice most efficiently. Also, you can customize your buildings according to your needs by upgrading them with different combinations of cards, increasing or changing their production, or changing their required dice value. Contribute to the building of Fredriksten to receive extra resources, and make sure to have your private army ready when Karl XII attacks.

… Desperate to maintain his immortality, a captain in the imperial army ventures deep into the uncharted jungle searching for the fabled Amulet of blood!

The game contains complete instructions for how you and your friends can explore a fantasy world; both in one-shot sessions that last a few hours and longer campaign games that take multiple sessions. A GM-less structured freeform game from Kiwi RPG Design, part of the UKRP Design Collective.

boardgame.name: Færdsels Teori
boardgame.description:
Everyone is a winner, because by playing this game you broaden the knowledge for traffic rules!

In FÆRDSELS TEORI your purpose is to answer questions correctly and gather the four tokens: Orange, Blue, White and Black.

There are four large fields (one in each corner) where you will get a token for correct answers.

From the center to the corners there are fields divided into Red, Yellow and Green.
If you land on RED your turn is over.
If you land on GREEN you can roll the die again.
If you land on YELLOW you will have to reply a question: Wrong answer will end your turn, a right answer will give you another go.

The winner is the one who got all four tokens AND returned back to Start where (s)he will have to answer correctly on FOUR out of SIX questions.

The best guide for designing story-filled locations

Where do the PCs go when they enter town? Inns, taverns and restaurants of course! But after dozens of such encounters in your games, these places have lost their novelty and excitement. It's time to shake things up.

Make it impossible for your players to take the table in the back corner by designing a round tower tavern. Tired of characters doing the cliche thing of never sitting with their back to the door? Design a jungle-themed room with four doors!

boardgame.name: Wiseguys
boardgame.description:
Set in the Golden Age of organized crime, players head rival crime families attempting to gain control of organized crime in the city. In the vein of Citadels, deceive your opponents and deduce their strategy as you gain wealth and respect in your rise to power. Plot and alter your own strategy as the game unfolds and as fortunes change hands quickly and unexpectedly.

Each round, players select characters through a secret draft. After all players have selected a character, they take their turns in order depending on the character they have chosen.

In the first part of each player's turn, they will use their character's tactic to their advantage to either earn cash, to take cash from their opponents, or to derail their opponent's progress in some way. Each character has his own unique tactic. As the game progresses, bluffing and deduction become increasingly important to gain an advantage over your opponents.

In the second part of the player's turn, each will have a choice of three different illegal operations to perform, and may perform any one of the three before ending their turn.

The first player to reach the required level of respect wins the game.

boardgame.name: Spaceward Ho!: Sci-Fi Combat and Role-Playing Game
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"The superdreadnought's shields were flaring in numerous locations, with more impacts every second, as they angled away enormously dangerous energy beams and deflected mass-driver rods. The titanic monster of a spaceship was engaged with an equally huge enemy carrier, and none had stood in it's way so long before..."

The game is designed to be as simple and versatile as possible. It aims to strike a good balance between the detail needed to give each vehicle its own character, and keeping information concise enough that large forces can be quickly created.

Any unit can be created, from the lowly and ubiquitous space marine, all the way up to planet-crushing space stations and superdreadnoughts. The game can even be used to simulate huge organic monsters able to go toe-to-toe with huge military spaceships.

Spaceward Ho! Lends itself very well to use as a rules-light role-playing game, but where many sci-fi role-playing games run into trouble when characters are confronted by vehicles and spaceships, Spaceward Ho! copes with these confrontations with ease.

boardgame.name: Vaporetto: Orbital Barge
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Vaporetto is a grav barge originally designed for use in and around the floating city of Tarazet. The grav barges also travel down to the planetary surface below, and up to orbiting space stations.

However, the Vaporetto saw its finest hour during a long-ago civil war. After a failed military coup 700 years ago, the popular government defended itself using militarized versions of the Vaporetto.

The most popular of these was the ‘Viper’ which had two squad support weapons mounted at the doors, operated by a pair of door gunners.

The original door gunners at the start of the coup were government troopers. Later, as the coup turned to civil war, the door gunner position often used non-military volunteers.

This supplement contains deck plans, artwork showing the four different variants, counters for use in space battles, and lots of background information. There are so many of these grav barges floating around the city that it's easy to flag one down and commandeer it. It is also easy to increase the armour and add door guns to make this design a formidable opponent in small skirmishes.

boardgame.name: Treatment Room
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This Product is a full-color, 16 x 10 inch, floor plan of a Treatment Room, with Hex, Square and No overlay.

This Product includes the VTT files for online play.

Includes a 360° View of the map.

Game Masters need quality maps for their miniatures. DramaScape™ is committed to bringing Game Masters the maps they need.

“Let’s go chop up this chop-doc!”

The treatment room is a single map of a surgery room. The product includes a 360-degree panoramic view of the room.

The treatment room is intended for use in modern or near future science fiction settings.

Adventure hooks for use with this product.

Hunt for a Madman: There have been a string of murders lately in a small town with victims found having their skulls opened and brains removed. The strange serial killings have rocked the small town bringing a media circus with them. The player characters are playing agents sent to solve the high profile case and take over for the overwhelmed local police force. They search the crime scenes, interview relatives, and try and find a link between the murders. Eventually, the group discovers that everyone murdered so far once worked at an asylum that was closed about twenty years ago. They find a list of people who work at the asylum and discover that only one person who worked at the asylum is left.

They rush to the scene, finding evidence of a struggle, but no victim. A car races off into the night and the agents scramble to their vehicles to chase them, leading to the killer’s house. The ex-asylum patient runs with the victim to his surgery room. The patient tries to strap down the survivor, use a bone saw to cut their skull open, and remove the brain screaming, “You examined my mind for so long, it is high time that I got to see yours!” If successful, he places it into a jar of formaldehyde before sealing it. If interrupted by the agents, he uses his bone saw and other surgical tools to cut them apart. After defeating the serial killer, the agents discover that the room has multiple brains in formaldehyde filled jars, one for each of the victims.

Surgical Complications: One of the party members may have lost an arm or leg in a recent firefight and now needs a replacement. A local chop-doc offers cheap biological and mechanical body part replacements. They find the chop-doc through a contact of the party. The group goes to the surgery room and they find it to be a dirty place, but the chop-doc is offering the lowest prices in town…

Meanwhile, the leader of a local group of thugs has been hunting this chop-doc for a while, having a seemingly good replacement put in that started malfunctioning a few weeks later. The faulty arm erupted with weapon fire, killing several of his men before they were forced to chop his arm off for their own safety. He wants the chop-doc dead and has sent his thugs to kill him after finding out where his surgery room is located.

The group finds themselves suddenly under attack from outside through the two southern windows. The chop-doc tells the rest of the group that the surgery won’t be completed unless they can buy him some time against the thugs. The chop-doc fixes the arm of the party member while the rest have to hold them off. Thugs also attempt to assault the main door, bringing wicked, rusted machetes with them hoping to exact a special kind of vengeance on the doc. When the surgery is completed, the group needs to finish off the thugs and escape since the cops are sure to be on their way by now.

boardgame.name: Hexopolis
boardgame.description:
Hexopolis is a fast-paced, intense strategy card game that includes tactical elements thanks to a dynamic board and zombies controlled by all players. Expect to be kept on your toes with cutthroat moves and counter-moves.

The game is won and lost by activating ingredients on the table; two different ones to win, two identical ones to lose.

Players start by creating the board from a set of hexagonal tiles around a tile marked as the Altar set in the middle of the table. Then, they draw five cards and play their move in turns.

The different actions from the cards include summoning zombies, moving them to specific tiles to bring ingredient cards from one's hand to the table, or sacrifice zombies on the Altar tile to activate or deactivate ingredients already on the table.
Cards can also be combined into advanced actions that bend the rules (steal cards, cancel actions, etc.).

Rules are in English and French. Cards are bilingual.

Comes as a printed-on-demand box or as a PDF file.

boardgame.name: Anki Drive
boardgame.description:
Anki DRIVE is a racing game like no other. It uses Artificial Intelligence (AI) and robotics to take the best of video games and combine it with the best of physical games. It’s a video game in the real world. You hold the cars in your hand, and the track rolls out on your living room floor.
You can play ANKI Drive against your friends, or against an AI-enabled opponent. The more you race, the more points you earn, which you redeem to upgrade your cars’ weapons and capabilities.

Source: The Developer Website.

User Summary

Anki Drive is a new breed of game... It combines elements of video games, real world interaction and RPG style leveling.

The cars are equipped with virtual weapons and other items. Each car has energy, you use this for your weapons and you could say your HP. If you run out of energy and you take damage from another car you get disabled. The car that disabled you gets a point for the KILL.

You play until someone gets 5, 10, or 20 points. At that time the game ends and the cars stop. You are assigned UPGRADE points for your performance in the match, that you can use to upgrade weapons or car performance. These points follow the player not the car, whereas the upgrades (most at least) follow the car. Just like a CCG you can trade the car with another player and the upgrades go with the car. If you earned UPGRADE points and have not spent them they stay with the player.

The more you play the better upgraded and equipped your car becomes, but you still have to drive it yourself. So even a poorly equipped car with a very good driver can win.

While not 100% a video game or an RPG it has the best of all worlds... Think CAR WARS for the modern day!!!

North America in 1871 is a land of adventure, opportunity, and conflict. Inventors from the American Consolidated Union supply automatons and steam-powered machinery to the oil fields of Texas and the mines of the Rocky Mountain Republic. Wells Fargo airships and steam carts compete with the Southern Pacific's monopoly on transcontinental rail travel. Native saboteurs raid across the borders from their home in the Plains Tribal Federation to destroy the technology that threatens their land.

Steamscapes: North America is the first setting book for Steamscapes. It includes extensive alternative historical backgrounds for the four most prominent nations of North America and offers six new professions with associated skills and edge trees, as well as the automaton racial template. It provides several introductory scenarios and a variety of character templates so GMs and players can jump right in and start playing.

Steamscapes: North America requires the Savage Worlds core rulebook to play.

boardgame.name: Flickin' Cars With Guns
boardgame.description:
Flickin' Cars With Guns is a tabletop dexterity game for 2 or more players playable in as little as 10 minutes. Players use diecast toy cars (like Hot Wheels or Matchbox) to represent armed vehicles. The goal is to destroy your opponents by shooting and crashing into them.

The game is meant to be played on a standard kitchen table, and you can use household items as obstacles and terrain. A 4'x3' table littered with plates, cups, and bowls is pretty standard. In fact playing a quick game after dinner, before cleaning up the table, is one of the funnest approaches.

Each turn the player "flicks" their car twice and shoots once. The act of flicking is where the physical skill and challenge of the game come in. Crashing into an obstacle hurts your car, and accidentally flicking off the table is penalized as well, so players have to be careful.

Shooting is done by rolling 2D6 with a to-hit target number equal to the number of inches to your target. So if your opponent is 8" away you need 8+ to hit. Double damage on double 6s, and shots always miss on double 1s.

There are several variants and optional rules that can be bolted onto this core system, such as droppable weapons, demolition derby mode, a drinking game, stunt bonuses, power ups, using playing cards, etc. to ensure plenty of longevity and suitability for all types of players.

boardgame.name: Rome in Crisis
boardgame.description:
Card game of the Roman Empire in the second half of the third century AD, a fifty-year period during which the average reign of an emperor was a mere 2.5 years.

Each player controls a number of imperial candidates whom they try to push to the top position to gain honor and prestige by solving some of Rome's many crises -- invasions by Goths, Persians and Palymrans plus the incessant demands of the populace -- before quickly yielding to the next emperor.

In a system reminiscent of King's Breakfast, players draft influence cards which they may later deploy to help them win top jobs in the empire or secretly use against opponents to make existing crises more difficult to handle. To gain power players must commit cards sufficient to outpoll the opposition and solve crises, but must avoid overcommitment that reduces future options and opportunities. In addition, each candidate has a different special ability which must be reckoned with.

At the end of play the player with the most prestige points wins.

boardgame.name: Milne Bay
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

"Australian troops had, at Milne Bay in New Guinea, inflicted on the Japanese their first undoubted defeat on land. Some of us may forget that of all the Allies it was the Australian soldiers who first broke the spell of the invincibility of the Japanese Army." —Field Marshall Sir William Slim

Defeated at sea in the battle of the Coral Sea in May and then distracted by the US Marine Corps landings on Guadalcanal, the Japanese High Command was forced to change its plans for New Guinea. After diverting the previously allocated Army regiment to reinforce Guadacanal, it fell to the Navy to gather a scratch force to capture the "lightly defended" airfield on the eastern tip of New Guinea.

Unfortunately for Japanese plans, those months of delays allowed Australia to finish assembling a brigade of Militia at Milne Bay during July, then rush a veteran AIF brigade there shortly before the Japanese landings commenced on August 25th, 1942.

Several scenarios are included in Milne Bay to allow players to explore different Australian and Japanese plans.

Pieces move, climb, rotate, capture, transform, and combine into new hybrid pieces as they surge across the board and off the Grid.

Grid-Hammer is themed on the Grid itself. What would an ecosystem populated by grid creatures look like?

boardgame.name: Battle Mice
Taisen Mouse
対戦マウス
boardgame.description:
Battle Mice is a near-perfect information card game for two players.

The deck consists of three identical sets of mice numbered 1–8. Each player receives one deck, then the last "neutral" deck is shuffled, two of those cards are put aside, and the rest dealt three to each player. Each player then places his first eight mice in a 3x3 grid with the middle square left empty. The neutral mice are kept as a hand of cards.

On a player's turn, he can move one mouse one step. A mouse that moves into the middle empty square has escaped, and the opponent's mouse with the same number is defeated (turned over). Each mouse has a special ability that affects only the two adjacent mice; for example, the fighter mouse protects the adjacent mice from being defeated, the nurse mouse heals a defeated mouse, the speed mouse allows adjacent mice to move twice, and so on. Each time a mouse exits, the active player can place a neutral mouse from his hand on one of the corner squares, if available.

At the end of the game, players receive one point per escaped mouse, but some of the mice give an extra bonus depending on the order in which they escaped. This order is determined by the two neutral mice set aside at the start of the game.

boardgame.name: GötzenDiener
ゲッツェンディーナ
boardgame.description:
GötzenDiener is a quick set-collecting card game.

The deck consists of five types of cards representing objects of worship, numbered 1–5, of various quantities. On a player's turn, he picks a card, then either keeps it or sends it to another player who cannot refuse the card. If a player gets a hand of four cards, he must discard all cards of any one type from his hand, applying the effect on those card(s).

The game ends when either the deck runs out, someone has a hand of three identical cards, or someone discards a 5. All players then show their hands, earning points for the most common object of worship in hand and the runner-up, and being penalized for everything else, those objects being heretical symbols.

boardgame.name: Cavern Crawl
boardgame.description:
In Cavern Crawl, players take on the role of one of 4 adventurers to explore the caverns, fight monsters and collect loot. It can be played either cooperatively or competitively.

Players start on the same "Start" card, and have slightly different attack, search and defense abilities depending on their character. On their turn, they first draw a map card and connect it to the already placed cards, expanding the caverns and creating more opportunities for battles and loot.

Combat and gaining coins works through dice rolls. Players have to beat certain defence scores of the enemies in their roll, and they gain the associated rewards if they're successful. This can also include treasure cards which provide bonuses and extra abilities.

Players can pool their dice rolls together if they are on the same space, to make it easier to gain rewards or defeat monsters. In this case, the rewards are split.

Players can also attack each other for the chance to steal coins from their opponents.

The goal of the game is to be the first to find 10 coins and make it back to the entrance. Each character has an additional secondary objective which provides an alternative winning condition.

boardgame.name: Fisherman's Profit
Ippou no arasoi
いっぽうのあらそい
鷸蚌の争い
boardgame.description:
Fisherman's Profit is a simple bluffing "outsmart the others" card game based on the Japanese proverb "If snipe and seashell fight, the fisherman profits", meaning that if two struggle, a third party wins.

From a deck of either blue or red seashells of different values, three cards are placed face down on the play area, and in turn, players peek at the unoccupied seashells, then place either a fisherman or a snipe on one of them. When all have placed, the seashells are turned up and resolved: Blue seashells can be taken only by snipes, and red only by the fishermen. If two have placed on the same, the latter will steal a previously claimed seashell from the former — but if both fisherman and snipe are on the same seashell, the fisherman profits according to the old proverb and both gets the seashell and catches the bird.

boardgame.name: Pariah
boardgame.description:
User summary:

A simple he-thinks-that-I-think card game.

Players have a set of cards numbered 1–6, where 6 is the king and 1 is a simple pawn. The back of each card is the Pariah, which is zero.
Each turn, players roll a die each and may play face down any card of that number or lower. All turned face up, and you count number of wins. The King wins over all cards except the fool (2), all other cards win over the fool. If a player has played a card higher than the number he rolled, he cannot turn the card, and it's a Pariah, which loses to all. Each win is awarded 1 point.

Every card has a special power, that usually affects his ability to play next turn. For example, the Pariah allows the player to not roll the die, but choose die result for the next turn.

This is repeated for 5 rounds, which counts as one hand. The player with most points after three hands wins the game.

boardgame.name: Cross Live
X-Live
boardgame.description:
User summary:

A solitaire card game based on the concept of rhythmic video games.

The player has a band of five dancers from a selection of 11, numbered 1–5. The dancers are put in a line, where each dancer is either in the front row or back row. From a shuffled deck of notes also numbered 1–5, five cards are lined up. Each turn, the cards of the lest represented colour will "fall down" (are slid down a bit) and must be "caught" by the team of dancers. However, in order to achieve a "perfect rhythm", a note must be caught by a dancer with the same number, if caught by a dancer with a number at most 1 more or less than the note is "good" if the note and the dancer are of the same colour; anything else is a "fail".
Before each catch, the player can only move one dancer one step, either from back row to front row, or sideways, in which case they swap places with whoever was beside them. However, moving sideways to a spot where no dancer is is not counted as a move, and will also cause the dancer who now ends up in the same column as the moved one, to move in the opposite direction, a so-called "cross move".

Being in the back row gives the dancer one extra turn to catch the note. Also, apart from the current row of falling notes, the player will have another row of notes above it, enabling the player to plan his moves one turn ahead.

The final score is decided by the number of perfects and good rhythm catches. Also, before each game, the player chooses which song to dance to; each song having a special effect on the game. Each dancer also has a special power to activate once per game.

boardgame.name: The Ravens of Thri Sahashri
Sanzen sekai no karasu
三千世界の鴉
三千鸦杀
boardgame.description:
The Ravens of Thri Sahashri is a two-player cooperative card game. One player is playing the girl Ren who has lost her memory; the other is the detective trying to repair it. The game is about trying to communicate as well as possible by simply the choice of cards. (Note: "Thri Sahashri" is the buddhist term for a trillion worlds combined, which in this case means "the other plane".)

Of a deck consisting of cards of five colors and numbered 1–5, the Ren player draws four cards and keeps them face down. The goal for both players is to ensure that when the hand ends, the playing field has cards of these colors and these colors only.

Each round, the detective draws as many cards as he wishes from the shuffled deck, putting them on the playing field according to the marks on the cards. The deck also contains ravens, which when drawn will "eat" any discarded cards of that color and threaten to take them out of the game.

When the detective player is done, the Ren player picks one of the cards in the playing field and puts on the leftmost still "incomplete" hidden card. A hidden card is complete when that card plus the cards placed on it total 7. (The fourth pile, however, should total only 5, according to the Japanese poem metric "dodoitsu" that goes 7-7-7-5.)

Once all four hidden cards are completed, the round ends and unless the playing field has exactly the colors represented among the hidden cards, the players have failed. The game is played for three hands, but in the final hand, one hidden card must be completed per round, lest the players fail. Players also fail if the deck runs out or if all five Ravens are drawn.

boardgame.name: COGZ
boardgame.description:
COGZ is a mad scientist strategy board game set in the steampunk era, where someone has broken the mad professor’s chromatic cogtraption!
You are a cognizant cogineer trying to repair the broken cogtraption before the professor returns. The other cogineers all seem to think they have the superior cognition needed to rebuild the chromatic device. It’s time to prove you are the true cogineer genius!
Hurry! You recognise there isn’t much time to do this incognito before the professor returns with his cog-nac…




How to Play

Cogineers are all swapping segments of the broken cogtraption to repair it. As long as the segment is different, cogineers gain cognition (game points) for doing so. When a mechanism is repaired fully it can no longer be modified by the other cogineers who all have their own agenda for repairs. There is bonus cognition and bonus turns to be awarded for clever repairs as well.

COGZ is a very simple game though it hides a huge amount of strategic depth which is normally discovered as cogineers gain experience. The best way to learn the game is to play the game. You can download the latest rules from the website (http://cogz.raez.net) and if you signup to the Newsletter you can also get the download link for the print and play version.




Game Play Features


Mensa Endorsed - COGZ has been tested by Mensa Members from a number of countries and has been endorsed by the High IQ Society Mensa.
Colour Blind Accessible - COGZ has been heavily tested with Colour Blind people with various visual impairments and optimised to be accessible to the common colour blind limitations.
Variants Included



COGZ included a book of variants. Tournaments, Team play, Different board layouts, 3D board setups and increase player range from 1-12 players.



Free Shipping - COGZ has free shipping to any international destination. It will also include VAT in Europe and GST in Australia.
Multiple Languages - COGZ has been translated into multiple languages. The latest rules can be downloaded from the website download section when they are complete.



Play Tested - COGZ has been play tested for almost 3 years and the game play has been repeatedly improved.
Wide Age - Both kids and adults can play COGZ and learn new skills and strategies as they progress.
Wide Skill - COGZ can be played very lightly right through to intense strategic planning.
Improve IQ - The more you play COGZ the better your pattern matching, planning and strategy will become.
Modular - The broken cogtraption is constructed from the Cog Tiles and provides infinite variations.
Elegant - The COGZ rules have been refined repeatedly to be as polished as a nice brass cog.
Competitive - In 2 or 3 players, COGZ can be incredibly strategic. COGZ Tournament variant is included.
Casual - In higher numbers of players (5 and 6), COGZ is more casual and social fun.
Simple - There are numerous layers of strategy in COGZ making it simple to learn but hard to master.





Game Component Features


1200dpi graphics
thick cardboard
linen finish on all components
cotton drawstring bag
foil logo printing on Drawstring bag
solid brass game gadget interscrews
game gadget functional gear mechanisms



COGZ will be available primarily via the RAEZ Shop shop.RAEZ.net and your favourite retail store.

boardgame.name: D.D. Dogma
boardgame.description:
D.D. Dogma is a party-style card game simulating the back-and-forth dialogue between roleplayers and the game master in an RPG session.

Each player selects a team of heroes from the available line-up, then receives six quest cards and a number of play cards that signify dice numbers.

Taking turns, players ask an opponent for a quest; that player unveils one of his quests, then the asking player tries to solve the quest by rolling as many dice as he has heroes, activating their abilities to generate resources such as "battle", "magic", "thievery" and so on. Each quest has its own clear requirements, and if the player manages to generate the correct resources, he gains the victory points the quest generates; if not, these points go to the quest owner.

After the dice roll, players can adjust the values of the dice by playing cards from their hands, either elevating, lowering or re-rolling the dice rolled. After this is done, the dice are applied to the lineup of heroes, activating different abilities.

boardgame.name: Binary
One Zero One
boardgame.description:
In the world of computer programming, there can only be one winner - either zeros or ones!

One Zero One is an abstract strategy card game for two players. With identical 16-card decks, each player (as either 0 or 1) plays cards to the program display, endeavouring to gain control of lines of program code. Each line is worth a set number of points. As soon as the program runs, points are tallied and the winner is determined.

Most cards display commands which will affect the cards already in play. The order and position of cards played by each opponent will have a huge bearing on the outcome, as will the ability of the players to adjust their strategies as the programming code changes.

Game #1 in 'The Mike Line' of games from Grail Games.

From the publisher blurb

In Dragonero GdR potrete visitare le terre descritte da Luca Enoch e Stefano Vietti, e magnificamente disegnate per Sergio Bonelli Editore. Dovrete risolvere enigmi che potranno condurvi alla morte, affrontare creature inquietanti e talmente minacciose che solo dei veri eroi come i protagonisti della serie a fumetti sarebbero in grado di affrontare, dovrete lottare per emergere fra torme di nemici che cercheranno, con l’astuzia o il confronto aperto, di farvi cadere e di cancellare financo il vostro ricordo dalle terre dell’Erondàr.

Costruito su un sistema esistente e conosciuto ma con meccaniche nuove ed innovative, Dragonero GdR è stato provato e sviluppato da un team completamente italiano sulla base delle aspettative dei giocatori, delle necessità della trama e dei meccanismi imposti dal bellissimo fumetto di Dragonero: una scoperta sia per i giocatori esperti che per i neofiti.

Nella scatola base troverete il
- Manuale di Gioco
- Mappa dell'Erondàr

English Translation by Google (with user corrections)
In the Dragonero RPG you can visit the lands described by Luca Enoch and Stefano Vietti, and wonderfully drawn for Sergio Bonelli Editore. You'll have to solve puzzles that could lead to your death, face creatures so threatening and disturbing that only real heroes like the characters of the comic series would be able to deal with, you will have to struggle to emerge from hordes of enemies that will try, through cunning or open confrontation, to bring you down and erase even your memory from the lands of Erondàr.

Built on an existing and known system but with new and innovative mechanics, Dragonero RPG has been tested and developed by an entirely Italian team, taking into account the expectations of the players, the needs of the plot and the mechanisms imposed by the beautiful comic Dragonero: a discovery both for experienced players and for newbies.

boardgame.name: Mythos Player's Guide
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Olympians have spoken and you are to join the ranks of heroes and heroines involved in the Heavenly Contest! The Olympian deities are in a race to find the successor to Zeus’s throne, with the successor acquiring the greatest number of followers. But the gods and goddesses are quite busy, and to shine their light upon the mortals of Hellas requires intervention of a divine scale. Heroic deeds are a must if one is to prove themselves worthy for the gratification of Olympus and the pursuit of seeing their patron deity rise to rulership! Are you strong, brave, and smart enough for the challenge? We will see how you fair against the great beasts of Hellas and the heroes and heroines who support your rival deity. This is the Heavenly Contest. This is Mythos!

In Mythos, you assume the role of a demigod or devoted human of the gods and goddesses of Olympus in a heroic mythological representation of Ancient Greece. Heroes and heroines join in the Heavenly Contest to prove their worth to the deities and spread the word of their patron deity to the mortals of Hellas, in hopes of raising their patron deity to the Olympus throne. Heroes and heroines come from all walks of life, representing their patron deity as adventurers, fighters, hoplites, Olympic athletes, courtesans, sages, and rogues. Through affiliations with deific cults and Mystery Cults, they gain access to great powers and follow the strands of Fate as they travel Hellas in search of their next, grand performance.

Inside the Mythos player's guide you will find:

An introduction to mythological Ancient Greece and the Heavenly Contest.
The demigod character race and its associated Divine Edges, more powerful than those you’ve seen before.
New Edges and Hindrances.
A completely new Arcane system to represent membership in one of the Mystery Cults.
A collection of patron deities from Greek Mythology.
Everything you need to create a Mythos character!

boardgame.name: Story
boardgame.description:
Can you tell a good story?

In the board game Story, you and your opponents match pictures, explain why they belong together and then vote for the player who told the best story. The reason why your picture is the best match is up to you. No explanation is more correct than another.

After each round, the players show who they have voted for and points are given accordingly. The player who receives the most votes is awarded 1 point. Every player who has voted for that player’s story receives 3 points. Each player receives between 0 and 4 points each turn.

The player that first reaches 20 points or more wins.

boardgame.description:
Welcome to the Dungeon — first released as Dungeon of Mandom — is a push-your-luck dungeon delve in which 2-4 players take turns essentially daring each other to go into a dungeon with less equipment than they start off with while filling the dungeon with monsters. Players can win the game by winning 2 rounds or get eliminated from the game by losing 2 rounds. Each player has a 2-sided players card that has a white side and a red side. The first win taps the player card and the 1st loss flips the card over to the red side. A 2nd loss will have the player turn the card back into the box.

The game is played in rounds. The player sets up the base character and all the equipment equipped. This represents every player as a fully equipped dungeon delver.

Each round, the start player (the person who challenged the dungeon last or the last player to be in a dungeon) can choose to draw a card from the monster deck or pass their turn.

If they choose to draw, they can do one of two things: (1) keep it and de-equip an equipment or (2) place it face down in the dungeon. Placing it face down in the dungeon creates the dungeon deck and fills the dungeon with monsters that the challenger will have to face later. If they choose to pass their turn, they cannot participate in the rest of the round. Once only one person is left after all the other players have passed their turn, that player then becomes the challenger and must go into the dungeon with only the equipment he has equipped.

The player then flips cards off the dungeon deck and fights the monsters within. Some equipment allow you to null the enemy damage or be able to withstand it by increasing your HP. If the player survives the dungeon with at least 1 HP, they win that round. If not, they lose. The players then reshuffles all the cards to make a new monster deck and re-equips all the equipment to start a new round.

The game ends when someone has won twice or one player is the last man standing.

Welcome to the Dungeon includes four different sets of character cards whereas Dungeon of Mandom has only a single character.

The game comes in two sets: the Starbox and the Moonbox. They can be combined for a larger game.

boardgame.name: Lords of Evil
Los Señores del Mal
boardgame.description:
Its not easy to be a Master of Evil. The working hours suck... Finding efficient minions is a pain... and keeping your well-earned treasure safe from the hands of the so called "Heroes" ends up being a full-time job. But... this is YOUR JOB and fame in the Inner Circle of Evil is everything to you so why not show the other Masters how a demonic job is really done! Masters of Evil is a game for 1 to 6 players where each player takes the role of an Evil Master that is repelling the attack of a variety of heroes trying to gain as much reputation as possible by imprisoning the heroes when defeated.

At the beginning of the game 5 hero cards are dealt to each player so 3 can be chosen. Those heroes will be attacking your Den. Each turn a Monster is Summoned and you will have to place one of your minion tokens on one of your heroes that have that monster symbol. If you complete a card by filling all the monster, traps, and spells symbols you defeat that hero and can claim it as a reward by imprisoning him/her into your dungeon cell. Some heroes provide a special reward when defeated... from adding an extra monster to getting a special Overlord ability.

After placing minions a die is rolled to determine if a type of hero attacks. To repel an attack you can remove monsters from that hero card for a value equal, bigger or lower than the hero attack (defined by the roll of 1D6). If you repel the complete attack you are undamaged. If you repel a portion you can get the rest of the damage by reducing your life (which begins with 10). Also you can simply nullify the attack of a hero by distracting them with one of your treasures. Spells can be used to change the summoned monster type and Traps can nullify any attack (even if they are not in the card of an attacking hero).

When the 6th hero is collected by any player the game is over and the scoring phase begins. Players get the points in the hero cards but also get points for the most types of each monster and if they collect at least 3 cards of a Hero Type.


No es facil ser un Señor del Mal. Las horas a las que hay que levantarse apestan... Encontrar sirvientes eficientes es un dolor de medula... Y conservar tu "bien merecido" tesoro de las garras de los heroes termina siendo un trabajo full-time. Pero es tu OFICIO y la fama adquirida en el circulo Interno de la Maldad lo es todo para ti... asi que porque no mostrar a los demas Señores como se hace un buen trabajo demoniaco! En los Señores del Mal los jugadores toman el rol de Señores Oscuros que estan repeliendo el ataque de audaces heroes aprisionandolos cuando son derrotados para asi ganar la tan preciada fama.

Al comienzo del juego se entregaran 5 cartas de heroe a cada jugador de las que seran elegidas 3. Esos heroes atacaran tu Guarida. Cada turno sera Invocado un Monstruo y tendras que colocar un token de minion en uno de los heroes que tenga en su carta a dicho monstruo disponible. Si completas todos los slots de la carta derrotas al heroe y puedes reclamar la recompensa aprisionandolo en una celda. Algunos heroes proveen recompensas especiales cuando son derrotados... desde otorgar un monstruo extra a darle al Overlord una habilidad permanente.

Luego de colocar los minions se tira un dado para determinar el tipo de heroe que atacara. Para repeler un ataque se pueden remover monstruos de la carta de dicho heroe por un valor igual, superior o inferior que el ataque del heroe (definido por un D6). Si repeles completamente el ataque no eres dañado. Si solo se repele una porcion recibes el resto del daño reduciendo tu vida (que comienza en 10). Tambien puedes anular un ataque entregandole uno de tus tesoros. Los hechizos pueden ser usados para invocar un monstruo diferente del que se ha invocado y las Trampas anulan cualquier ataque (incluso si no estan en la carta del heroe atacante)

Cuando un jugador aprisiona a su sexto heroe el juego termina y comienza la ronda de puntaje. Los jugadores obtienen puntos por cada heroe capturado, pero tambien por mayoria de determinado tipo de monstruo y variedad de heroes.

boardgame.name: BattleTech Adventures: Necromo Nightmare
Necromo Nightmare
boardgame.description:
From the introduction

The year is 3072. The fires of the Word of Blake’s Jihad threaten to consume the Inner Sphere. On the borders of Capellan space, the vital world of Necromo has suddenly gone silent, perhaps the victim of a Blakist strike. But what could hit such a busy and well-defended planet so hard that even the Chancellor’s best would fail to call for help?

Time to find out…

BattleTech Adventures: Necromo Nightmare takes players to the dark world of Necromo, on the Confederation’s border with the Federated Suns—a world mysteriously silenced by a lightning attack by unknown forces. Can your team discover the cause of this shipyard planet’s unexplained blackout, and live to tell the tale? Necromo Nightmare includes a guide to this important world, personal biographies on several key players, and adventure Tracks designed for use with A Time of War: The BattleTech Role-Playing Game and the A Time of War Companion, as well as special rules, terrain guides, maps, and Record Sheets for key non-player characters and equipment unique to this story.

boardgame.name: Steampunk Tower
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Steampunk Tower is a tower defense game with several unique mechanics. First, there is only one big central tower on which the various cannons are purchased and placed. Second, the central tower gets higher as the game proceeds, so there are more floors on which to place your cannons. Third, you can move your cannons around on different floors and/or change their orientation. Finally, you can upgrade your cannons and play additional challenge levels. These will test your tactical skills but will also reward you with many extra points!

boardgame.name: Berserk: Knights and Villains
boardgame.description:
Berserk: Knights and Villains can be played on its own or as an expansion for Berserk: War of the Realms. The cards in Knights and Villains are a bit simpler than in the base set, but that does not mean that it is less interesting to play with them.

At the beginning of the game, you choose your side — Knights or Villains — then you recruit your army. All the creatures in this game have a cost, life, movement and basic strike, and some have additional abilities written on the card. The random factor in this game is a die; any player may use regular d6 die, or a special d6 die for attack or defense. Players place their creatures on the battlefield and the game begins. You can move and act with your creatures in any sequence.

Berserk: Knights and Villains includes both quick play and full rules inside the box.

boardgame.name: Prisoner's Dilemma: Camp 16
boardgame.description:
You remember the outside world and you remember liking it. But by now, you’ve been in Camp 16 so long, you’re forgetting what it looked and felt like. Inside the camp you face certain death, outside the camp you face starvation, sickness, bitter cold, enemy territory, and even death at the hands of your own comrades. Struggle is life. In Prisoner’s Dilemma: Camp 16 you play as either Prisoner #75044 or Prisoner #44233, two prisoners unaware of their crime, and hungry for freedom.

In this two player game, each player has a prisoner, and chooses one of three possible win conditions (Martyr/Survivalist/Comrade). Players will take turns reading a scenario, then bargaining with their fellow prisoner to come to a conclusion about whether to choose a selfless [o] path or a selfish [x] path. Based on the combination of the two player’s choices, players will take or gain damage according to the Results table beneath the scenario. If the players survive and meet their individual win conditions, they win. If they die, they lose. You must make good decisions to keep yourself alive, though sometimes that may mean making personal sacrifices in order to stay alive in the long run.

boardgame.name: Sexism
boardgame.description:
Your goal in Sexism is to move from the doll house to the White House, with the first player to cross the finish line winning. What you win, however, depends on your gender and whether you proceed to the "Man's Goal" or the "Woman's Goal". If you win as a woman, the game instructs others that "You are now a person and must be treated as such for 24 hours"; if a man, you receive a cartoon of a large thumb pushing a woman down and a declaration that "Congratulations, you've won — or have you?"

Gameplay consists mostly of drawing cards, reading the text on them (e.g., "You're all for women's liberation, but nobody's going to catch YOU going to a woman doctor. Go back one step."), then moving forward or backward as dictated. Some cards require the active player to act out a role, then others guess who or what the player was trying to be.

The game rules suggest playing as the opposite gender "because this can cause some hilarious role-playing situations".

A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Spoils of War
Juego de Tronos: El Juego de Cartas – Botín de Guerra
Le Trône de Fer: Le Jeu de Cartes – Butin de Guerre
Il Trono di Spade: Gioco di Carte – Bottino di Guerra
boardgame.description:
"Your prize will be the doom of you. Krakens rise from the sea, Theon, or did you forget that during your years among the wolves?"
–George R.R. Martin, A Clash of Arms

Spoils of War is the first Chapter Pack in the "Conquest and Defiance" cycle for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game. In Spoils of War, each of the six Great Houses of Westeros enjoy the plunder and glories of their victories...even as those trophies place them at risk to lose their positions of power. Among the Chapter Pack's sixty cards (three copies each of twenty individual cards), you'll find captives, spies, vengeful schemes, righteous fury, and deadly, crippling treachery.

Many of the new cards from Spoils of War feature the "prized" keyword, which balances tremendous risks and rewards in deck-building and play. These cards lend material, in-game value to the riches you plunder, the captives you seize, and the castles you successfully siege. But can you hold them once you win them? Prized cards give your opponents power when they enter your discard or dead piles, so it’s up to you to leverage your spoils toward victory!

If the convicts' HP reach zero, the guards win.

boardgame.name: Deductio
boardgame.description:
Deductio is a French card game for 2-8 players.

The rules of the game

Beginner

Choose the number of cards you want to play with. To start, 3 cards per player are dealt.

Example : you have 3 players and you decide to play with 3 cards. Take the numbered cards from 1 to 10. Mix them up, and distribute them face down. The last card is placed onto the table.

The oldest player begins. He multiplies a couple of his cards and then announces the result.

Example : the first player has cards 2, 5 and 8. Consequently he can associate 3 couples of cards : 2 and 5, 2 and 8, 5 and 8. He chose the first and declares : "10".

His opponents have to deduce which couple it is.

Example : to obtain 10, you can either have the 2 and the 5, or the 1 and the 10. In that case, the second player has the 1 : thus he validates the first hypothesis.

Players take turns in a clockwise direction declaring a multiple, until one player has identified which card is on the table. He says "Deductio" and declares the number of the hidden card without showing the card to the others. If he is right, he scores a point. If he can identify the cards in each player's hand without any mistake, he scores a bonus point, and the hand is over. If he is wrong, he loses 1 point and the hand goes on.

The first player to score 10 points wins the game.

Experienced

Play with 4 cards or more following the same rules. The number of possible couples (for example, 6 couples for 4 cards) and the multiples related to each value increase.

In turns, each player can play the joker card. He puts it in front of him and turns it face down once used. It will allow him to pass his turn once without declaring any number. It can be played at any time.

boardgame.name: Hostile Takeover
boardgame.description:
In the not too distant future the world is ruled by massive corporations that wage war with each other over the control of empires. Literal wars fought by private armies proved to be overly costly in resources, profits, and public opinion, so the Wolf & Phoenix Marketing Conglomerate introduced an out-of-the-box way for corporate entities to resolve their differences: The Hostile Takeover Arena. Corporations that have reached an impasse in negotiations can avoid expensive, lengthy legal battles or risky sabotage by simply hiring a team of trained warriors to out-maneuver the competition in a quick, bloody, ratings-exploding spectacle.

In Hostile Takeover, players control a mercenary team trying to outwit and outgun the competition. Each Character has strengths and weaknesses that must be wisely used to gain the upper hand. Can you lead your team of mercenaries to victory amid the chaos of battle?

Hostile Takeover is played on a modular board (usually 30”x30”) filled with 1” Squares. Force fields and other terrain features are placed on the board to simulate a sci-fi battle arena. Players each use their team of 4 mercenaries to accomplish scenario specific objectives that earn them victory points. The first player to earn enough victory points (determined by scenario and number of players) is the winner. Each scenario is specifically designed to bring all teams together in a flurry of combat.

At the start of each Round players select an Action Card (Move, Melee, Fire or Aim/Overwatch) for each of their unwounded characters. Players also assign 4 Energy Tokens to their characters. Energy Tokens are used to boost the characters in a variety of ways and also enable the use of each character’s unique Special Action. Players then roll for Initiative. Finally, players go in Initiative order activating 1 of their characters. This continues until all characters have acted or become pinned or wounded. There is a quick Clean Up step at the end of the round and then a new round begins.

Ranged and Melee Combat checks are handled by rolling 3d6 and trying to equal or exceed a given target number. Each Character has a chart describing their ranged and melee weapons that quickly and easily provides the target number to roll against based on a variety of factors.

boardgame.name: Albiele Island
boardgame.description:
From the introduction

Albiele Island is a haven to some of the worst scum to ever sail an ocean. Pirates, smugglers, slavers and similar sorts all use the island as a convenient place from which to ply their trades throughout the seas of southern Anuire. The island is slightly over 50 miles long and varies from 6 to 25 miles in width. Albiele Island is in fact one of the few pieces of the once mighty Deismaar range not swallowed by the Straits of Aerele.
The western end of the island is heavily wooded. A low range of hills extends down the centre of the island for most of its length. Steep cliffs protect a small, natural harbour which is the home of the thriving Albiele Town. Sparse plains and empty beaches make up the rest of the island’s geography. Each of the areas of the island is presented in more detail below.

boardgame.name: Dig Down Dwarf
boardgame.description:
Dig Down Dwarf is a dice game in which each player takes on the role of a dwarf chieftain in line for the throne. In the game, you roll dice to obtain gems from the mine. Gain the most valuable collection of gems, and you'll be crowned the new dwarf king!

On your turn, you draw two random gems from the bag and place them on the table. You then roll four six-sided dice. Certain gems require a certain number sequence in order to mine them; roll that sequence, and you can take all the gems of that type! As the game progresses, more and more gems will be added to the table, giving players choices as to which gems they want to try to mine. Sometimes you'll need to press your luck in order to succeed.

Once the bag runs out of gems, you enter the final round, with players needing to do their best to snag the last gems.

boardgame.name: Carnival Arcane: The LARP
boardgame.description:
publisher blurb

Despite the popularity of big circus attractions, small carnivals still tour the American countryside in 1928. While most carnival-goers seek only diversion and entertainment, a few want something more, something that cannot be found in the everyday world of light and reason, and the Lancaster-Rigby Carnival is rumored to offer what no one else can.

The carnival train arrived yesterday in the New England coastal town of Warren's Rock. Opening-day receipts were fair, but the day isn't over. Tonight, for one night only, Lancaster-Rigby presents the Carnival Arcane.

The tents are up, the lights are strung, and the barker is ready to show you in....

Figments of Your Imagination (FYI) proudly presents Carnival Arcane: The LARP, the first in our licensed series of live action scenarios inspired by the horror-themed music of Midnight Syndicate. Based on their acclaimed album, Carnival Arcane, this scenario allows players to step into the roles of characters from the album and townsfolk, some with dark secrets, some with powers that defy explanation, and some with murder in mind.

During the day, Lancaster-Rigby is much like other carnivals, its colorful tents and avenues lined with clowns, side-shows, animal acts, games of skill and chance, and caramel popcorn. However, at midnight, long after most people have gone to bed, the carnival lights come back on and the gates swing wide, admitting anyone brave or desperate enough to contact the Other Side, or buy potions that heal incurable maladies, or procure supernatural means to fight one's enemies, real or perceived. The Carnival Arcane doesn't deal in sleight-of-hand or bottles of snake oil. Within its confines, patrons will experience true power, true miracles, and perhaps true fear. Of course, all such things come at a price, and those who willingly enter the Carnival Arcane must also be willing to pay....

The 96-page book contains everything you need to run this exciting event:

• Simple rules that keep the action moving
• Comprehensive plot summaries
• Detailed character sheets
• Informative and enlightening player handouts
• Prop, decoration, and menu suggestions
• Extensive Game Master notes
• General advice on running LARPs, such as finding locations and attracting players

Our narrative-style character sheets clearly explain each character's past as well as their secrets, goals, and resources. Multiple story lines give every player a chance to get involved. Note that this is a plot-driven LARP with no boffer (foam weapon) combat. The landscape format makes it easy to read both onscreen and in print.

Carnival Arcane: The LARP is written for 11-20 players and one or two GMs, with a suggested running time of 4-5 hours. Try our easy, fast-playing rules, or use your favorite system. The album Carnival Arcane is not included nor required, but we strongly recommend playing it in the background during the event, to help set the mood and create the proper atmosphere.

You and your friends will traverse the vast desert on your flying carpets, from the most grandiose palace in the capital city to the lonely dunes of the night, hunting down every nasty, slimy ghost – and hopefully, even catch them!

But there’s also the supernatural side to it (who needs ghostbustin’ heroes when there’s no ghost?); evil spirits, levitating djinns, and six hundred year old sultans that refuses to die because they can’t find their shoes. All eager to spread fear and havoc.

boardgame.name: Dragon Kings World Book
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Khitus is a world in decline. New heroes must emerge to challenge the wicked before all is lost …

The benevolent Dragon Kings who ruled over Khitus have inexplicably vanished, leaving once-powerful nations at the mercy of foul creatures. Cold Skins and Krikis grow numerous and bold. Desperate cities of the Old Countries struggle against savage marauders who draw ever closer to their crumbling walls. Ancient wizard schools guard their tomes, essential to their dark sorcerous bargains, more jealously than ever, while the followers of a mysterious prophet rekindle the magic-that-is-not-magic. The essential materials of life and civilization are ruthlessly plundered by the mysterious Pretenders in their Black Fortress, leaving the southern lands, especially, in dire straits.

Adventurers must face the wrath of a violent world, not only to survive but to right these wrongs, protect the innocent, discover the fate of the Dragon Kings, and reintroduce some semblance of justice to a world on the brink of destruction.

Dragon Kings is a new fantasy game setting conceived and presented in fiction, art, and music simultaneously. Written by Timothy B. Brown (creator of Dark Sun and 2300AD), Dragon Kings is the spiritual successor to the popular fantasy setting, Dark Sun.

Dragon Kings includes:

 · A hardbound game book
· A progressive rock CD
· An art-intensive, concert-style book that expands heavily on each song (with lyrics, stories, maps, more art, and so on)

With the PDF available in March 2014, and a planned hardcopy shipping date of June 2014, the game book is rules-agnostic, with PDF supplements for different game systems (Pathfinder, Savage Worlds, FATE, and 13th Age).

Each song on the Dragon Kings progressive rock epic album follows our hero's life from his desperate stand against mercenary raiders to his enslavement on the mighty caravans and his subsequent escape and encounter with an ancient, gentle folk who impart mysterious truths about Khitus, the world of the Dragon Kings…

Every song has its own two-page spread in the album book, expanding upon the material and bringing it to life. Contributors include Timothy Brown, Mike Stone (formerly of Queensryche), Mark Stevens, and Frank Klepaki.

 That’s Dragon Kings: a fantasy world envisioned and created in fiction, art, and music all at once!

boardgame.name: Mechabrick: Gangs of Neon City
boardgame.description:
Mechabrick is a range of precision molded plastic kits to convert your minifigs into 1/144 scale fighting robots or 'mecha'. You can upgrade your mechs with weapons and accessories and then battle for supremacy in a fast-paced board game using buildings and scenery built from your favourite plastic toy building bricks.

The first game in the Mechabrick product line is Gangs of Neon City. Set in the back-streets of a futuristic far-eastern metropolis the game uses durable plastic gaming boards (supplied in the game box) printed with a brick-standard grid pattern (4-bricks square) upon which movement and shooting range of the robots is measured.

It's up to you and your imagination to build, change and rebuild the buildings and scenery on your game board from plastic toy building bricks and create your perfect battle environment.

The game sets two or more players in a head-to-head battle of turn-based play using 'action points' to choose whether each robot should move, shoot or both in each turn. Customisation and upgrades to your robots are key to a decisive win, but be careful not to weigh down your mech with too many upgrades and make them too slow to fight!

The printed rulebook supplied with the boxed game is only 4 pages long and is designed to be fun and fast-paced for all the family. We will be publishing free add-ons and expanded rules for the game to keep even the most hardened gamers interested for many years to come.

The boxed game includes four of the 'Wakazashi-Class' mech kits (two black and two white), four plastic game boards, a decal sheet to customize your mechs and your scenery, two D6 dice and a full rule/instruction booklet.

boardgame.name: Zeppeldrome
boardgame.description:
Zeppeldrome, is a serious steampunk race through silly obstacles with a hazardous, modular board and cards that are used to help you or mess with opponents as you all race to be the first to travel the length of the airship raceway.

Game-Play
Each turn, players look at the top half of the cards in their hands and choose one that shows the route they will attempt to take that turn in their effort to get past (or through) silly, yet hazardous, obstacles. The players reveal the chosen flight plan cards simultaneously.

Next, each player uses the often silly, but always strategic, actions on as many of their remaining cards as they like. These actions will either disrupt their opponents, or help themselves (or both).

Once card-play is finished, the last-place player moves any obstacles that need moving on the board (such as the falling Lemmings in the "Tragic Lemming 'Migration'"), and then the players move their dirigibles along the now-final path that resulted from their initial plan, plus cards that were played on them.

As players move, obstacles on the board (including the other players’ dirigibles) affect movement in positive or negative ways (depending on how skillful and lucky the players were in their card-play).

The first player over the finish line is the winner!

boardgame.name: Sheepland
boardgame.description:
A sunny land of rolling green meadows, lush forests, and majestic mountains. The peaceful, happy people of the island want nothing more than to roam the land with their fuzzy little flocks of fluffy white sheep. All is well and good, until somebody has the bright idea to put up some fences…

Now the shepherds must compete for the most profitable lands to raise their flocks, driving the sheep to the lands they own—and fencing them in so they don’t wander off and join some other shepherd’s flock!

And then there’s that strange black sheep that keeps showing up. His rare black wool is certain to fetch a pretty price in the market for the shepherd that can pen him in!

Can you corral the finest herd in the best lands and become the richest shepherd in Sheepland?

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Collapsible D: the Final Minutes of the Titanic
boardgame.description:
Collapsible D™: the Final Minutes of the Titanic is a riveting game of survival set during the last dramatic minutes on board the Titanic.

The goal is to save your Passengers, each worthing victory points, on the lifeboats. The faster you will save them, the more points you will get. While you lead your passengers to safety, the icy waters of the Atlantic Ocean quickly flood the gigantic hull.

Collapsible D™: The Final Minutes of the Titanic is released to commemorate the centenary of the distaster of the british passenger liner. On 14 April 1912, on her maiden voyage, RMS Titanic sank after the collision with an iceberg.

Source: The Developer Website.

These are additional cards made by gaming industry veterans and bonus cards that can be added to enhance Adventurer: The Card Game. They were made available from retailers, web orders, and other venues:


Golden Portal: Found only in the Limited Edition Castle Deck
Shade the Trickster: This is a Guest Designer Card by Gary Gygax. This is available from the website and from select retailers. We also have the great honor in knowing this is also the very last thing Gary designed before he passed away in March.
Warden's Pool of Darkness: This is a Guest Designer Card by James M. Ward and pays homage to the great gold box Dungeons and Dragons game he help create to the computer. This is available from the website and from select retailers.
Blunderbuss: This is a Guest Designer Card by Chris Clark. This is available from the website and from select retailers.
Slooch the Cleric: This is a Guest Designer Card by Tom Wham. This is available from the website and from select retailers.
Count Lodrac: These are extra Lodrac cards that you can add to your game to increase the chance of finding the vampire and likewise speeding up the game. This is available from the website and from select retailers.
Lodrac's Twin: This is an extra hero card that you can add to your deck to allow for more players.. This is available from the website and from select retailers.
Crown of Immortals: This card is free when you refer a friend to buy the game.

boardgame.name: Invasion Z
boardgame.description:
Invasion Z is a Zombie Survival Game. The story is about an outbreak of Zombie-like creatures after a Meteor disintegrates in the atmosphere raining a strange color into Buenos Aires City. This rain causes the population to get sick and then die, only to become the dreaded ghouls that crave for the flesh.

Gameplay has 5 basic steps:

1) MAINTENCANCE: Operatives untap all the used items and Profile card, and Mission penalties are applied to the main Counters.

2) OPERATIVES STEP: Heroes move around the board, hunting zombies, rescueing people, finding useful items and trying to avoid the inevitable fate that awaits them.

3) ZOMBIES MOVE: All zombies move closer to the base in the center of the board.

4) EVENTS STEP: Depending on the levels of the Event Counter one or two events might happen. A special die is rolled and the event takes effect.

5) ZOMBIE STEP: Depending on the levels of the Zombie Counter one or two extra zombies will be added to the Zombie Roll. Usually 1 die per rescuer is roll (between 3 and 4 die total) plus any extra die added by the Zombie Counter placing zombies in the suburbs of the map. A 6 rolled is a miss and do not adds any zombie.

The objective of the game is to rescue the 8 survivors that stand hidden on the locations of the outer ring of the board and then return to the center tile to be retrieved by the rescue team.

The Heroes lose if at any time there are 3 zombies on the central location tile.

The Items deck works as a counter that will increase the difficulty as the game progresses with some "bad luck" cards that can be a devastating force against the heroes.

There are several ways of losing the game and only one way to win so usually players will feel very rewarded when they win as it´s usually on the edge of oblivion.

boardgame.description:
"Crossroads" is a game series from Plaid Hat Games that tests a group of survivors' ability to work together and stay alive while facing crises and challenges from both outside and inside. Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game, the first title in this series, puts 2-5 players in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world in which most of humanity is either dead or diseased, flesh-craving monsters. Each player leads a faction of survivors, with dozens of different characters in the game.

Dead of Winter is a meta-cooperative psychological survival game. This means players are working together toward one common victory condition, but for each individual player to achieve victory, they must also complete their personal secret objective, which could relate to a psychological tick that's fairly harmless to most others in the colony, a dangerous obsession that could put the main objective at risk, a desire for sabotage of the main mission, or (worst of all) vengeance against the colony! Games could end with all players winning, some winning and some losing, or all players losing. Work toward the group's goal, but don't get walked all over by a loudmouth who's looking out only for their own interests!

Dead of Winter is an experience that can be accomplished only through the medium of tabletop games, a story-centric game about surviving through a harsh winter in an apocalyptic world. The survivors are all dealing with their own psychological imperatives, but must still find a way to work together to fight off outside threats, resolve crises, find food and supplies, and keep the colony's morale up.

Dead of Winter has players making frequent, difficult, heavily-thematic, wildly-varying decisions that often have them deciding between what's best for the colony and what's best for themselves. The rulebook also includes a fully co-operative variant in which all players work toward the group objective with no personal goals.

Deal of Winter
If you come across a great sale of Dead of Winter
Option 1: Don't buy it. You are miserly and don't want to bring the joy of gaming into your life, no matter the low cost. You click away from the game listing, but accidentally click twice, triggering an unrelated banner ad on a page you had open earlier. Your computer is now infected with a virus. Reduce Morale.
Option 2: Buy the game. Hooray! Everyone suddenly likes you and you're the life of the party! As you pick up your package containing the game, a dog approaches. He's friendly, has no owner, and is inexplicably wearing a cape. You name him Sparky. Only later do you find out that this is a character in the game, too. It feels like kismet. The dog even saves your life one day, but you never find out about it (well, except for now).

"Crossroads" is a game series from Plaid Hat Games that tests a group of survivors' ability to work together and stay alive while facing crises and challenges from both outside and inside. Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game, the first title in this series, puts 2-5 players in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world in which most of humanity is either dead or diseased, flesh-craving monsters. Each player leads a faction of survivors, with dozens of different characters in the game.
Dead of Winter is a meta-cooperative psychological survival game. This means players are working together toward one common victory condition, but for each individual player to achieve victory, they must also complete their personal secret objective, which could relate to a psychological tick that's fairly harmless to most others in the colony, a dangerous obsession that could put the main objective at risk, a desire for sabotage of the main mission, or (worst of all) vengeance against the colony! Games could end with all players winning, some winning and some losing, or all players losing. Work toward the group's goal, but don't get walked all over by a loudmouth who's looking out only for their own interests!"

boardgame.name: VludKin ClaNz
boardgame.description:
Developer Summary

VludKin ClaNz is a card game for two players about the struggle of the VludKin for control over the Vlud, the energy upon which their world is built. Each player starts with two VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and their goal is to not have the lowest influence VludKin when the game ends, and therefore be the player controlling the Vlud.

This is an original "stack-building" card game for two players, with a set of rules that are quick and simple to learn, but offering numerous strategic options and dirty tricks on the path to victory.

Each player receives two random VludKin cards from different ClaNz, and during the game they draw a card from the central deck which they then try to win with one of their VludKin, rolling over that VludKin's Influence modified by the card. If this card is an Influence card, they can then place it under one of the VludKin, altering their Influence value based on the Clan type shown on the card. If it's a Power card, then they can carry out the special action on that card before it is discarded.

Failing to win a card will earn the VludKin a -1 Influence token to their total, and they can get rid of these only through trading an Influence card matching their Clan or the use of certain power cards, which might actually move all the tokens to an enemy instead. If an Influence card is failed, then the other player gets a chance to win it. If a Power card is failed, then the power is automatically played by the enemy VludKin opposite; sometimes it's in your advantage to fail a Power card...

During the game, the stacks of cards under each VludKin are built, changing their Influence up and down over turns until the game ends and the player with the lowest VludKin loses. With the ability to play Influence cards on the other player's VludKin and with the use of Power cards to move Influence cards around the stacks, a level of strategy is added to the simple core rules.

The game ends when either a VludKin reaches ten Influence or the central deck is empty, so through the use of Influence and Power cards a tense game builds in which the balance of Influence can change right up to the end on the asymmetrical board game playfield. There is little down time for the players and no hidden hands of cards, so this provides an exciting head-to-head experience.

VludKin ClaNz comes with eight VludKin from four ClaNz, two copies of each of the twelve different power cards, and forty Influence cards. Adding extra sets of the Power and Influence cards gives you the option to customize the central deck to how you want to play, and also gives the option for a longer game.

Can you gain influence over the VludKin in this original card game?

Free RPG Day 2013 Character for use with Shadows of a Black Sun

From Introduction:

Sin comes from a long line of bounty hunters and learned many of their ways, even though she did not join in the family business. The Rodian came to Coruscant ten years ago seeking ever larger fortunes and wrestled her way into the property market. What Sin thought was an innocuous deal turned out to involve the Pykes, and they made sure she would profit more if she undercut her original client deeply. In time, Sin came to appreciate the world of crime and what could be accomplished working outside of the system.

boardgame.name: Tray'Essek
boardgame.description:
Free RPG Day 2013 Character for use with Shadows of a Black Sun

From Introduction:

During a bounty hunting job, fellow clansman Lar’omx betrayed and humiliated Tray'Essek, which according to his beliefs “zeroed out” his jagannath points, denying him a place of honor in Trandoshan society and in the afterlife. The only way to restore his lost points is to kill the one who did this to him. Tray'Essek has devoted his life ever since to killing Lar'omx…and making sure that nobody else kills him first. Last he heard, the traitor was working for Black Sun, and Tray'Essek joined up with the Pykes recently for a chance to finally track Lar’omx down.
